Core Course: Macroeconomic Management New Methods and Current Policy Issues III
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Fumika Ouchi Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-5058
Number 32 March 1999
Moreno-Herrero, Blanca The Economic Policy and Poverty Reduction Division of The World Bank Institute conducted a core course on Macroeconomic Management: New Methods and Current Policy Issues III in Washington, D.C., from December 7-9, 1998. This course was the third of the 6 offerings scheduled for the fiscal year 1999 under the Macroeconomic Management series. The first two courses were held in July, 1998, in Turkey (Series I) and in October, 1998, in Cote d'Ivoire (Series II). Series I and II targeted policy advisors and economists from Government Ministries and academic institutions. They focused on participants' capacity-building in macroeconomic analytical skills based on extensive training in quantitative methods and techniques during a 10-day session. The Washington course, Series III, was a 3-day session that was designed primarily for professional macroeconomists at the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The course reviewed analytical and methodological advances in macroeconomics with an emphasis on policy issues. A total of 31 participants attended the Washington course, consisting of Bank/IMF staff as well as representatives from academic and research institutions.
The WBI Evaluation Unit conducted a Level I (participants' reaction) evaluation using a participants' feedback questionnaire. The questionnaire consisted of three sections. The first section asked the extent to which respondents were satisfied with course content and delivery. The second section asked the level of respondents' knowledge about course topics before and after the course, based on self-assessment. A 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1=minimum to 5=maximum was used for each question. The third section was respondents' open-ended comments about the course. The questionnaire was completed by 24 respondents, 77.4% of the total participants. Seven respondents (29.2%) were women. In the analysis of course content and delivery, the course was compared with the two previous course offering in Turkey (Series I) and Cote d'Ivoire (Series II). Since the Washington course was different from the first two Series in terms of targeted audience, course structure and length, the analysis was limited to the comparison of selected indicators measuring the overall usefulness of the course, relevance of the course to current work, and the quality of instructors. Series I was attended by 24 participants and had a response rate of 79.2%, whereas Series II had 42 participants and a response rate of 92.9%.
Respondent Background in Washington Course
l Twenty-two out of the 24 respondents (91.7%) were Bank/IMF staff and 2 respondents (8.3%) were from academic/research institutions. All respondents except one had either doctors degrees in economics or in other areas (N=15, or 62.5%), or masters degrees in economics or equivalent (N=8, or 33.3%). One person reported having virtually no formal study in economics.
l Respondents had different years of work experience in the field of economics. Of the 20 participants who responded to this question, 10 (50%) had less than 10 years, 6 (30%) had 10-19 years, and 4 (20%) had more than 20 years of experience. Nearly half of the respondents indicated that they were interested in keeping themselves  half of the respondents indicated that they were interested in keeping themselves updated on the most recent quantitative analysis in economics. Fifteen respondents (62.5%) reported to have followed at least some current research literature closely on quantitative methods, and 11 (45.8%) reported having had a formal training in quantitative techniques within the past five years. Although demographic questions were limited in the two previous course offerings, at least 60% of the respondents in Series I and II also reported having closely followed up on the latest quantitative methods through training and literature.
l Respondents represented all of the Bank's geographical regions except one region, South Asia. Regions that the respondents identified as the areas of their responsibility at work were Africa (N=9), Europe and Central Asia (N=6), East Asia and Pacific (N=4), Latin America and the Caribbean (N=4), and Middle East and North Africa (N=3). Respondents were allowed to select more than one region on this question. Three respondents indicated their areas of responsibility as "global."
Course Content and Delivery
l The overall usefulness of the course received a mean score of 3.92 out of 5.0. This was one of the highest ratings in this evaluation, with approximately 80% (79.2%) rating either 4 or 5 on this indicator. When asked to describe the most useful aspect of the course, 9 out of the 19 respondents (47.4%) who provided written comments noted that the course brought them up-to-date on the latest literature and research models in the field of macroeconomic policy issues. It was indicated, however, that the rating of the course's overall usefulness was much lower in the Washington course, compared with the two previous course offerings. The past two series of this course had received mean scores of 4.53 in Series I and 4.32 in Series II.
l One possible reason for a relatively lower rating in the course's overall usefulness in Washington may have been associated with varying levels of relevance of the course to respondents' work. The indicator measuring the relevance of the course to current function was 3.74 in Washington. While 14 out of the 24 respondents (58%) indicated the strongest relevance to their work by rating either 4 or 5, the remaining 10 respondents (42%) selected a rating of 3 or below on this indicator. Four respondents (17%) reported the minimal relevance of the course to their current work by rating either 1 or 2. In the two previous courses, the relevance to current work received 4.63 (Series I) and 4.44 (Series II) out of 5.0. All respondents in Series I, and 85% in Series II, rated either 4 or 5 on the course's relevance to work. For respondents in Washington the course was more relevant to their personal learning needs (mean=3.96). It was evident from their comments that respondents in Washington found at least some part of the course related to their work, and beneficial. As one respondent suggested, however, the course organizer is advised to take steps to ensure that prospective candidates know detailed course contents in advance, in order for them to be able to decide whether the course is relevant and appropriate for them to attend.
l On the quality of instructors, respondents in the Washington course reported high levels of satisfaction that were similar to those observed in the two previous offerings. More than 90% of respondents in the Washington course rated either 4 or 5 on the question that asked about the instructors' knowledge about the issues, giving the highest mean score in the evaluation, 4.33. This item was 4.32 in Series I, and 4.38 in Series II. The effectiveness of instructors in communicating messages was 4.09 in Washington, 4.26 and 4.08 in Series I and II. The five most common suggestions provided by the respondents concerning the instructors' presentations were: 1) try to avoid focusing only on instructors' own working models in the presentation; 2) allow  participants to debate over the materials just presented; 3) cover fewer materials in one presentation with more time; 4) ensure that each session start on time and avoid ending the day after 6 p.m.; and 5) distribute the reading materials in advance for better preparation.
Self-Reported Knowledge
l Respondents' self-reported ratings of all 12 issues presented in the course improved after the course, from the 2.45-3.43 range before the course to the 3.22-4.0 range at the end of the course. Respondents, who were mostly Bank/IMF economists, indicated having a fair knowledge of at least 5 subject issues before entering the course by giving a rating exceeding the mid-point on a 5-point scale, 3.0. They include "Consumption and Saving" "Investment," "Banking Crisis and Monetary Policy," "Exchange Rate Management I," and "Exchange Rate Management II." By contrast, two topics that respondents reported as the least familiar areas before the course were "Fiscal Decentralization" and "Stabilization Policies, Poverty and the Labor Market." At least 30% of the respondents (N=8) gave a rating of either 1 or 2 out of 5 on these two items in their pre-course ratings.
l One of the key topics, "Stabilization Policies, Poverty and the Labor Market," was presented in two separate sessions: "Analytical Issues" and "Case Studies." Although designed to address the same issue, the two sessions had different reactions from the respondents. At the beginning of the course, respondents' knowledge of the contents presented in the two sessions were among the lowest (mean=2.45 and 2.50, respectively). Upon completion of the course, one of the items, "Analytical Issue"" had an increase in rating by 45%, the largest gain in knowledge reported by the respondents (mean=3.55). The other item, "Case Studies," also had a positive gain (29%) but did not improve as much as "Analytical Issues." Respondents reported the lowest post-course knowledge level on the "Case Studies" among all topics (mean=3.22). This suggested that the "Stabilization Policies, Poverty and the Labor Market" may require some adjustment to improve its effectiveness of the case study approach.
l A number of respondents commented on specific presentations as particularly valuable presentations for them. At least 5 respondents mentioned "Exchange Rate Management," "Capital Flows and Financial Market Integration," and "Consumption and Saving" for their clarity in presentation and interest of the issues.
